review.body:
A steam punk version of Jack and the beanstalk. After helping out Rapunzel, Jack heads back to the city of Shyport to rescue his mother.
The wonderful illustrations show a diversity of characters and the action is suited to the Steam Punk look.
Blaylock's plot pays homage to Vern and Poe, while at the same time, he also has a great deal of fun.

book.title: A Fool and His Monet (Serena Jones Mystery, #1)

review.body:
A little different book than I am accustomed to from this author, but a good read nonetheless. A Fool and his Monet bell the story of Serena Jones and adventures with recovering artwork that has been lost or stolen. She gets a call about a Monet that is missing and goes to work
Serena is not you...
Just, no.

book.title: The Nine Pound Hammer (The Clockwork Dark, #1)
book.publisher: Random House Books for Young Readers

review.body: While at times elements of "Harry Potter" shadow some of the action, Bemis's plot is original as a blend of Steampunk and American folklore.

Amazing

I believe that only few people can write this well and that is why we only know few authors .

The plot is set in Middle Anglia, Eastern Britain, 631 AD. Essa and his father, Cai have the unique position of being slightly outside the clan while still having social connections.
Moran blends historical detail with fantasy to create a fascinating story.
Mann's plot is primarily a murder mystery, although it does have the prerequisite trappings associated with Steampunk. The murders featured in the story are similar to the Jack the Ripper case.

book.title: HiLo: The Boy Who Crashed to Earth
book.publisher: Random House Books for Young Readers

review.body: Loved it!

She hoped that the parents of the dead little girl whose black hair she braided and formed into the figure of a bird didn’t mind if there were a few tears mixed in among the locks.

review to come.

read it for yourself here:

http://www.tor.com/2012/10/23/too-fond/
Hunt really knows Science fiction. Within his plot there is refernce to Ray Bradbury, and Huxley. Professor Amelia Hunt is a female version of Indiana Jones, with action and adventure included.

Oh my. I read this book in the 8th grade: I can say it was one of the only time my whole class were so engaged in a activity. Always talking about what we thought was going to happen next. Truly good memories come to mind when I think of this book.! Recommend it to anyone!

book.title: And Then There Were None: Play

review.body: I loved the version and having read the book after I would say it's a very faithful adaptation. It's what got me into the mystery genre!

Solid addition to a satisfying series
The Hook Personal goal to work my way through this series.

The Line “The woman had long journeys in her voice and I liked that.”

The Sinker – The character of Harry Bosch captivates me. I believe this is due to his blend of a hard-core, rough-edged cop who can t...
Mehhhhhhhh a herd we have seen them before .........
Not really wanting to read the next book, except am curious of the new addition. With this book I skimmed it a lot it's has lost my interest.

A 16 year old boy, whose body is riddled with disease, accepts the opportunity to have his head cryogenically preserved on the off chance that some year in the far future he may be reattached to a body and brought back to life. Five years later, the unbelievable has happened. This is a funny, tou...

While out on an excursion, Ottoline meets Cecily Forbes and her pony. The two girls become friends and when Cecily goes off to Alice B. Smith School for the differently gifted, Ottoline decides she wants to go along.
Riddle's illustrations have a quality very similar to Dr. Seuss, in that they are...
Review pending

book.title: The Octopus: A Story of California

review.body: Excellent saga of the railroads vs the wheat farmers in Central California in the 1880's. The book depicts the author's fictionalized account of the Mussel Slough tragedy. This is a slow read, written in 1901, in the style of older writers. Nevertheless, I loved it!
